title: Morning MoneyBeat Europe: Europe Weighed Down by Mining and Oil
text:

Follow us on Twitter @WSJMoneyBeat. 
European markets are seeing familiar laggards Thursday. The Stoxx Europe 600 was down 0.4% in early trade, following a 1.3% gain on Wednesday, as oil and gas companies fell 1.3% before recovering a little ground. The falls were led by BP PLC, whose shares were down 3.1% and Tullow Oil PLC, off 4.4%, as the persistent decline in oil prices continued to drag them down. Mining stocks continued to be under pressure from the commodities slump. Miners in the Stoxx 600 fell 1.1% and Anglo American PLC and BHP Billiton PLC were among the bigger fallers. 
But earnings season is also taking a toll. The biggest loser in the Stoxx Europe 600 Thursday was Danish biotechnology Novozymes A/S, which was down 12.4% after cutting its sales growth forecast. 
Weak results also weighed on Deutsche Post AG and Zurich Insurance Group, which were down 2.6% and 3.6%, respectively. German retailer Metro AG climbed after posting a net profit for the second quarter. 
Bank of England watchers are bracing themselves for an unusually large barrage of information Thursday that should offer fresh clues as to when officials are likely to raise interest rates. 
The BOE is due to publish minutes of the Monetary Policy Committee’s deliberations alongside its monthly policy decision for the first time. The minutes, which include a record of how individual policymakers voted, are usually published with a two-week lag. 
The central bank will also publish its quarterly inflation report, a 50-page collection of economic forecasts that’s invaluable for investors trying to work out officials’ next move. 
More broadly, of course, investors are waiting for Friday’s U.S. jobs report for July for more guidance on the timing of the first increase in interest rates in nearly a decade. The Federal Reserve considers employment and inflation data as it makes decisions on monetary policy. 
Read our full take on the European markets today here. 
-- Christopher Whittall 
Market Snapshot: At 8.50 a.m. GMT, FTSE 100 down 0.29%, CAC 40 down 0.12% and DAX up 0.05%. Nikkei closed Tuesday up 0.24%. Brent crude up 0.32% at $49.74. Gold down 0.12% at $1084.3. EUR/USD down at $1.088. Ten-year Treasury yield lower at 2.27%, Bund yield lower at 0.69%, Gilt yield lower at 1.99%. 
What You May Have Missed on MoneyBeat 
Lloyds Bans All-Male Shortlists for Top Jobs: Lloyds Banking Group has told recruiters that shortlists for jobs from assistant vice-president level upwards will no longer be considered unless one-third of the names on the list are women, and that headhunters’ contracts could be in doubt if they failed to comply. 
‘Super Thursday’ to Offer Signal on U.K. Rate Outlook: Bank of England watchers are bracing themselves for an unusually large barrage of information Thursday that should offer fresh clues as to when officials are likely to raise interest rates. 
Apple Dealt Fresh Blow With Wall Street Downgrade: Is Apple turning sour? Well Bank of America Merrill Lynch is certainly turning more cautious. Analysts at the U.S. investment bank have cut their share price target for the technology giant to $130 from $142 and changed their recommendation to ‘neutral’ from ‘buy’. 
It’s a Credit Pickers’ Market, Says Hedge Fund Manager Hintze: Corporate bond yields may be close to all-time lows but now is the best market for hedge funds investing in U.S. and European bonds for four years, according to a well-known London hedge fund manager. 
Blog Post from College Student Causes Massive Sell-Off in AAC Holdings: Investors shrugged off AAC Holdings, Inc.’s disclosure last week that its former president and several former employees had been indicted by the state of California for “second-degree murder” of a patient at one of the company’s substance-abuse treatment centers, but a blog post sent the stock reeling Tuesday. 
Why U.K. Homeowners Should Care About the Fed: As investors increasingly expect the Federal Reserve to soon raise borrowing costs in the U.S., fresh research suggests a rate rise could have an impact on a sizable group of people across the Atlantic: British homeowners. 
Mom and Pop Buck Trend to Snap Up Physical Gold: Mom and pop’ investors are back in the business of buying physical gold. Gold prices tanked in July, but the U.S. Mint had its best month for gold coin sales in two years, while a U.K. bullion trading website reported a surge in buying. 
As ESPN Loses Viewers, Some on Wall Street Move to Sidelines on Disney: Walt Disney Co. shares are down in the dumps. The stock is off as much as 10% Wednesday, having its worst intraday performance in four years, after the company missed revenue expectations Tuesday amid slower growth at its media networks and parks segment. 
Bill Winters Posts Tough First Quarter at Standard Chartered – 5 Takeaways: Standard Chartered posted weak first-half earnings, as expected, with net profit sinking to $1.46 billion from $2.31 billion on lower revenues and rising bad loans. Here are the key takeaways. 
From The Wall Street Journal 
Activist Ackman Takes $5.5 Billion Stake in Snacks Giant Mondelez: High-profile activist investor William Ackman has built a $5.5 billion stake in Mondelez International, a giant bet that the maker of Oreo cookies and Ritz crackers will become the biggest target in a wave of consolidation reshaping the food industry. 
Plane Debris Confirmed as MH370: An aircraft part that washed ashore on an island in the Indian Ocean last week is from long-missing Flight 370, Malaysian officials said, making it the first concrete evidence of the plane that disappeared 17 months ago in one of the world’s most confounding aviation mysteries. 
Silver Can’t Bear Up: Like gold, silver has lost its shine among investors who are no longer seeking a shield from market turmoil or a store of value to protect against inflation. Silver’s use as an industrial metal is also on the wane as growth in world economies, particularly China, starts to slow. 
U.S. Probes Och-Ziff Africa Deal Tied to Mugabe: Authorities are investigating whether the hedge-fund firm knew that part of a $150 million investment in an African miner would wind up with Zimbabwe’s government. 
Adidas’s Second-Quarter Earnings Rise Slightly: Adidas said Thursday its second-quarter earnings rose slightly, helped by a healthy sporting goods market in general and strong sales in China and Western Europe. 
Commodities Slump Slams Rio Tinto Earnings: Rio Tinto said first-half net profit plunged from a year earlier, as the Anglo-Australian miner grappled with a sharp slump in prices for commodities such as iron ore, coal and copper. More from The Wall Street Journal
